overview_of_class: The course will explore the nature and scope of black popular music across the African diaspora. We will reflect on what is "black" and what is "popular" about this broad and varied expression, and consider the ways in which the music both represents for black life and is expropriated by mainstream society. The course will help uncover the role music plays in social activism and in the critique of power structures. We will examine how this role problematizes black music's understanding as entertainment.
name: Selected Topics for Non-Majors
title: MUSIC GEN_MUS 335-0-20 Selected Topics for Non-Majors

overview_of_class: By using music, this course introduces students to the delights and understanding of great Russian poetry. Professor Irwin Weil explains the historical and cultural background of some of the outstanding works by Russian Poets. Dr. Natalia Lyashenko, formerly the choral conductor of a major Russian opera company, conducts rehearsals of operatic choruses from operas based on works by these poets. The students, coached in the language by Professor Weil, get to sing in a concert exhibiting the beauty of music created by Tchaikovsky and other Russian composers. No previous knowledge of the language or the music is required.
